channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Houthis Launch More Missiles Toward U.S. Ships
item.description: The U.S. military said the Iranian-backed Houthi militia struck an American-owned container ship, a day after a missile aimed at a Navy destroyer was shot down. No injuries were reported aboard the cargo ship.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Houthi supporters protesting U.S.-led airstrikes in Sana, Yemen, on Friday.

item.title: They Thought They Knew Death, but That Didn’t Prepare Them for Oct. 7
item.description: Volunteers with ZAKA, an Israeli group that recovers dead bodies, were among the first to reach the victims of the Hamas-led attacks. The trauma of what they witnessed may last a lifetime.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Maya Levin for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Weissenstern, left, Menachem Weissenstern, Israel Ganot, Yossi Weisenstern, Duby Weisenstern and Efi Epshtein, all volunteers with ZAKA, last month in Yesodot, Israel.

item.title: Taiwan Loses Ally Nauru After Electing President Beijing Loathes
item.description: The tiny Pacific island of Nauru severed relations with Taiwan, a move that boosts China’s regional sway and was seemingly timed to Taiwan’s contentious recent election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Sam Yeh/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tien Chung-kwang, Taiwan’s deputy minister of foreign affairs, condemned the island nation of Nauru’s decision to break diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

item.title: Iran Adds Prison Time for Narges Mohammadi and Frees 2 Journalists
item.description: Narges Mohammadi, the jailed human rights activist, was sentenced to additional prison time, while journalists who reported on the death of Mahsa Amini were freed for now.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Fredrik Varfjell/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ali Rahmani, son of Narges Mohammadi, spoke onstage during the 2023 Nobel Peace Prize ceremony at Oslo City Hall in Norway last month.

item.title: Iceland Faces ‘New Chapter’ of Seismic Activity as Lava Menaces Town
item.description: The country has many earthquakes and eruptions, but now, “a daunting period of upheaval has begun” in the southwest, the president said.
item.dc:creator: Egill Bjarnason and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Icelandic Coast Guard/via Reuters
item.media:description: Lava approaching the town of Grindavik, Iceland, on Sunday. The authorities have ordered residents to evacuate.

item.title: Everton Faces Second Points Deduction Over New Financial Case
item.description: The Premier League announced charges against Everton and Nottingham Forest, increasing the risk that both clubs could be relegated at the end of the season.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Jason Cairnduff/Action Images, via Reuters
item.media:description: Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite, top, in a game against Aston Villa on Sunday. Everton currently sits one position outside the Premier League’s relegation zone.

item.title: ‘The Social Contract Has Been Completely Ruptured’: Ireland’s Housing Crisis
item.description: Soaring rents have left many struggling to afford homes in Dublin and have created a generational divide. Two-thirds of younger adults in the city live with their parents.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction cranes last month in Dublin. For years, house building in the Irish capital has focused on short-term rentals or luxury.

item.title: The War Has Reined In Ukraine’s Oligarchs, at Least for Now
item.description: Oligarchs have lost billions from the shelling of their factories, and the government has used its wartime powers to break their political influence.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel factory in Mariupol in 2022. With the destruction of Azovstal, Rinat Akhmetov, the plant’s owner, lost an industrial jewel accounting for one-fifth of Ukraine’s steel output.

item.title: War or No War, Many Older Ukrainians Want to Stay Put
item.description: The front line in Ukraine is largely peopled by the elderly these days. Some can’t afford to get out. Others say they won’t abandon their homes.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraida Kurylo, 83, at home in September.

item.title: As Development Alters Greek Islands’ Nature and Culture, Locals Push Back
item.description: As a proliferation of pools threatens some water supplies and housing costs skyrocket, people of the Cycladic islands say the Aegean islands’ character is being lost to real-estate homogenization.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Livadi port in Serifos, Greece.

item.title: New Leader Takes Over in Guatemala, Raising Hopes for Fragile Democracy
item.description: Bernardo Arévalo, an anticorruption crusader, had to fight to make it to Sunday’s inauguration. His challenges are just beginning.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernardo Arévalo, the president-elect, leading a protest last month against an attempt by government institutions to interfere in the results of the elections. Prosecutors and judges opposed to Mr. Arévalo have taken steps that have raised doubts about whether there would even be a transition of power.

item.title: Why Taiwan’s Election Matters to the World
item.description: Tensions over the island’s status have flared repeatedly for decades, especially as Washington’s relationship with China has grown more strained.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Lai Ching-te, who won his presidential race, at a campaign rally in Taipei on Saturday.

item.title: At Least 5 People Die Trying to Cross Icy English Channel
item.description: French authorities said that a ship carrying migrants trying to reach Britain had been “reported in difficulty” off the coast of northern France. More than 30 people were rescued.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Bernard Barron/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A French military ship patrolling in the English Channel on Sunday as seen from the beach in Wimereux, in northern France.

item.title: Whisky From Wales? Believe It, Say the Welsh.
item.description: It is no simple task to get an official seal of approval for a bottle of Welsh spirits. Persuading purists to give it a try may also be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aber Falls single malt whisky is produced in a distillery filled with the strong malty aroma of barley in Abergwyngregyn, Wales.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A Houthi attack on a U.S.-owned ship.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Houthi supporters protesting U.S.-led airstrikes in Sana, Yemen, on Friday.

item.title: Houthis Attack More Ships in Red Sea After U.S.-Led Strikes in Yemen
item.description: The Iranian-backed militants launched a fresh round of attacks days after their military sites were hit by U.S. and British forces.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yahya Arhab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A funeral in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday for Houthi fighters said to have been killed in U.S. and British airstrikes.

item.title: Iran Hits Iraq and Syria With Missiles, Citing Terrorist Attack
item.description: Explosions shook Erbil, a city in northern Iraq, and at least four civilians were killed, local officials said. Syrian targets were also hit, Iran’s Revolutionary Guards said.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Safin Hamid/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A market in Erbil, Iraq, last year. A missile attack on the city on Tuesday killed four civilians, local officials said.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Houthis Attack a U.S. Ship
item.description: Also, the Iowa caucuses and Indigenous tourism.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: U.S. Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Houthis fired at the U.S.S. Laboon on Sunday. Here is the ship, in a 2015 photograph taken off Greece.

item.title: UK Moves to Ban the Islamist Group Hizb ut-Tahrir
item.description: The government said it would designate the international Islamist political group a terrorist organization, citing what it said was Hizb ut-Tahrir’s praise for the Oct. 7 attack on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Hizb ut-Tahrir rally in London in 2006.

item.title: Months After Cyberattack, British Library Crawls Back Online
item.description: Britain’s national library made the first major steps in its recovery process after a ransomware group took down its website and online catalog.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British Library in London in April.

item.title: Car-Ramming Attack in Israel Kills 1, Police Say
item.description: Two Palestinian men were arrested, according to the police, who said the incident was being treated as a terrorist attack. The French government said two of those injured were French nationals.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Nir Keidar/Reuters
item.media:description: Damage from a reported ramming attack in Ra’anana, near Tel Aviv, on Monday.

item.title: Hamas Says Two More Israeli Hostages Are Dead
item.description: The group said the two were killed by Israeli airstrikes, which the Israeli military said was at least partly false.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Amir Levy/Getty Images

item.title: Israeli Soccer Player Sagiv Jehezkel Detained in Turkey
item.description: The player, Sagiv Jehezkel, displayed a pro-Israel message after scoring on Sunday and was promptly suspended by his club. He was released after questioning and returned to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Adem Akalan/DHA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mr. Jehezkel pointing to a message on his wrist that included a Star of David and the words “100 days, 7.10.”

item.title: Workplace Wellness Programs Have Little Benefit, Study Finds
item.description: An Oxford researcher measured the effect of popular workplace mental health interventions, and discovered little to none.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workplace wellness offerings such as apps, coaching and courses in time management or financial well-being did not have any positive effect, according to the study, while resilience and stress management trainings seemed to have a negative effect.

item.title: New U.S. Solar and Electric Car Factories Face Familiar Challenge: China
item.description: Worries are growing in Washington that a flood of Chinese products could put new American investments in clean energy and high-tech factories at risk.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times
item.media:description: A solar panel factory in Perrysburg, Ohio. Some Biden administration officials are concerned that a flood of Chinese imports could threaten the survival of U.S. factories.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: 100 days of war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli tanks in central Gaza this month. They were photographed during an escorted tour with the Israeli military.

item.title: Congressional Leaders Unveil Stopgap Bill to Head Off Shutdown
item.description: The bill would extend government funding through early March, teeing up a race to pass the bipartisan deal into law before an end-of-week deadline.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill, formed from a spending deal negotiated by Speaker Mike Johnson, right, and Senator Chuck Schumer, would extend funding until March.

item.title: Nicaragua Frees Jailed Catholic Bishop and Other Clergymen
item.description: Two bishops and 17 other clergymen were freed after Pope Francis drew attention to the government’s persecution in his New Year’s Day address.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Yubelka Mendoza
item.media:credit: Ezequiel Becerra/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nicaraguans in San José, Costa Rica, demonstrating this month against the detention of priests in their country.

item.title: Guatemala’s New President Is Sworn In, Despite Efforts to Stop Him
item.description: For hours, it was unclear whether Bernardo Arévalo, an anticorruption crusader, would take office at all, as lawmakers delayed the transfer of power.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Bernardo Arévalo of Guatemala and his vice president, Karin Herrera, greeting onlookers from the balcony of the National Palace to celebrate their inauguration on Monday.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Wage a Proxy War
item.description: Iran wants to flex its muscles without directly taking on the U.S. or Israel, but that cautious strategy is subject to miscalculation on all sides.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes, Vivian Yee and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: U.S. Central Command, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released Friday by the U.S. Central Command reportedly shows a missile being launched from a warship during the U.S.-led operation against Houthi targets in Yemen.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Houthis Hold Firm After Strikes
item.description: Also, Taiwan’s president-elect and India’s court case backlog.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Houthi fighters and tribesmen at a rally against the U.S. and the U.K. strikes on Houthi-run military sites near Sanaa, Yemen, on Sunday.

item.title: Cheered by Thousands, King Frederik X Takes the Throne in Denmark
item.description: The prime minister publicly presented the new monarch, King Frederik X, after his mother formally completed her abdication as queen in a private meeting.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Wolfgang Rattay/Reuters
item.media:description: Denmark’s newly proclaimed King Frederik, Queen Mary and their children appearing on the balcony of Christiansborg Palace on Sunday.

item.title: Who Is Lai Ching-te, Taiwan’s Next President?
item.description: A former doctor with a humble background, Mr. Lai is seen as more attuned to the mood of Taiwan’s people than to the perilous nuances of dealing with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and John Liu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Lai Ching-te has been described as a skilled, hard-working leader attuned to sentiment in Taiwan.

item.title: Israel Vows to Keep Fighting Hamas in Gaza
item.description: The prime minister of Israel struck a defiant tone after hearings at The Hague, where Israel has been accused of genocide.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli tanks in central Gaza this month. They were photographed during an escorted tour with the Israeli military.

item.title: North Korea Test-Fires Intermediate-Range Ballistic Missile
item.description: The launch, the first by the North this year, indicates that the country may be developing a new missile that could threaten U.S. military bases in the region.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A news broadcast on Sunday in Seoul with file footage of a North Korean missile test.

item.title: Video: Iceland Volcano Erupts in Same Area as December Event
item.description: The latest eruption happened along a row of volcanoes on the Reykjanes Peninsula, where a fissure opened in December, creating a river of lava.
item.dc:creator: Egill Bjarnason and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Icelandic Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management, via Reuters
item.media:description: A volcano spewing lava on Sunday on the Reykjanes Peninsula in Iceland in a photograph released by its civil defense agency.

item.title: Much of Houthis’ Offensive Ability Remains Intact After U.S.-Led Airstrikes
item.description: The strikes damaged the group’s ability to carry out complex missile and drone attacks, U.S. officials said, but identifying targets has proved to be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sayed Hassan/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen have launched repeated strikes at ships in the Red Sea.

item.title: China Failed to Sway Taiwan’s Election. What Happens Now?
item.description: Beijing loathes the new president, Lai Ching-te. He aims to protect the status quo with caution and American help, but tensions are likely to rise.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Lai Ching-te in Taipei after his win on Saturday, a third successive victory for the Democratic Progressive Party.

item.title: Lloyd Austin Confronts the Perils of Being a Private Man in a Public Job
item.description: President Biden said his defense secretary made an error in judgment in not keeping the White House informed of his hospitalization. But keeping a low profile has long defined the Pentagon chief.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, the former commander of United States Central Command, brought 40 years of service with him when he took the top Pentagon job in 2021.

item.title: Houthi Militia Threatens to Respond to U.S. Airstrikes as Crisis in Gaza Grows
item.description: Officials of the Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen threatened to respond to American-led airstrikes over the past two days.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Fatima Shbair/Associated Press
item.media:description: Palestinian children line up for a meal in Rafah, southern Gaza, where food is scarce, last month.

item.title: Antihero Worship
item.description: The Emmy Awards are next week. Does it matter if you like the characters on the nominated shows?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Russian Dissident’s Fraught Path to Canadian Citizenship
item.description: Maria Kartasheva was sentenced in absentia by a Moscow court for criticizing the war in Ukraine, threatening her citizenship application in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Kartasheva at home in Ottawa. A Russian dissident, she was sentenced by a Moscow court to eight years in prison for spreading “false information” about the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Regains Upper Hand in Ukraine’s East as Kyiv’s Troops Flag
item.description: Ukrainians are weary, short of ammunition and outnumbered, and their prospects look bleak. “We can stop them for now, but who knows,” one soldier said. “Tomorrow or the next day, maybe we can’t stop them.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier from the 68th Brigade at a trench 500 yards from Russian positions in Ukraine’s eastern Luhansk region, earlier this week.

item.title: One Man’s Mission to Revive an Indigenous Language in Argentina
item.description: Blas Jaime has spent nearly two decades resurrecting Chaná, an Indigenous language in Argentina that he learned from his mother.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba and Sebastián López Brach
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Blas Omar Jaime has, in many ways, placed the Chaná Indigenous group back on the map.

item.title: Russia Launches Large-Scale Missile Attack on Ukraine
item.description: The assault was in line with a wider air campaign that Russia began in late December, seeking to wear down Ukrainian air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Alina Smutko/Reuters
item.media:description: People taking shelter inside a metro station during an air-raid alert on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern, Former New Zealand Prime Minister, Is Married
item.description: New Zealand’s pathbreaking former prime minister became a global celebrity noted for, among other things, a very long engagement.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Felicity Jean Photography, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An official photograph from the wedding of New Zealand’s former prime minister Jacinda Ardern and Clarke Gayford on Saturday in Hawke’s Bay, New Zealand.

item.title: Threatened by Premier League Fan Zones, Burger Vans Hold Their Ground
item.description: As Premier League clubs create fan zones to collect yet more money from stadium visitors, a local economy of food trucks, pubs and small restaurants is holding its ground.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tony Aujla’s Burger Bar outside Villa Park in Birmingham, England. Mr. Aujla has been a fixture outside the stadium, in one place or another, for more than four decades.

item.title: In Taiwan, Voters Choose President as China Tensions Loom
item.description: Taiwan’s vice president, whose party has emphasized the island’s sovereignty, defeated an opposition party that favors reviving engagement with China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwan’s vice president, Lai Ching-te, won the island’s presidential election on Saturday.

item.title: India’s Court System Is Hopelessly Backed Up
item.description: With 50 million criminal and civil cases pending, it would take 300 years to clear the country’s judicial backlog.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Elke Scholiers
item.media:description: Lawyers outside the Delhi High Court. The number of pending cases in the Indian judicial system has doubled over the past two decades, to more than 50 million.

item.title: Ecuador’s Attorney General Took on Drug Gangs. Then Chaos Broke Out.
item.description: Explosive revelations by the country’s top prosecutor showed links between cartels and officials, a move that might be “kicking the hornet’s nest.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Soldiers detaining a man after curfew on Friday morning in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

item.title: U.S.-Led Strikes Leave Yemen Back on the Brink of War
item.description: Yemen’s Houthi militia, shaped by years of civil war, says that it welcomes a battle with the United States and that strikes will not stop its Red Sea attacks.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Saeed Al-Batati
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Yahya Arhab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest in Sana, Yemen, on Friday against a U.S.-led operation targeting Houthi military sites.

item.title: U.S. Leads Second Strike Against Houthis in Yemen
item.description: The military fired at a target in response to rising attacks on Red Sea shipping, which the Houthis linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Helene Cooper and Thomas Fuller
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Yahya Arhab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest in Sana, Yemen, on Friday against the operation to safeguard Red Sea shipping with U.S. and British airstrikes on Houthi military sites.

item.title: Tesla and Volvo to Pause Production in Europe After Red Sea Attacks
item.description: The carmakers said they would suspend production at their plants in Germany and Belgium because of supply chain snarls linked to the attacks in the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tesla said its factory in Grünheide, Germany, will temporarily suspend production starting Jan. 29.

item.title: Gaza is Facing Yet Another Communications Blackout
item.description: It is the ninth blackout the enclave has endured since the war began in early October.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Haitham Imad/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for missing people under the rubble after Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, on Friday.

item.title: How Women’s Soccer Is Embracing Mental Health
item.description: Elite soccer didn’t always welcome players’ requests for help. Scandals, attitudes and support programs are changing that.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: United States Women's National Soccer Team
item.media:credit: Luisa Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Sinead Farrelly at the 2023 Women’s World Cup in Australia, far from her darkest days.

item.title: C.I.A. Homes In on Hamas Leadership, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: A new task force at the spy agency is also working to boost intelligence collection on hostages still held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Israel for a mother and two daughters killed in the Hamas attacks. A C.I.A. task force was assembled to gather information after the Oct. 7 attack in Israel.

item.title: With Genocide Case Against Israel, South Africa Challenges Western-Led Order
item.description: After arguing its genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, South Africa won praise for standing up for Palestinians under Israeli bombardment in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Remko De Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: South Africa’s minister of justice, Ronald Lamola, and the South African ambassador to the Netherlands, Vusimuzi Madonsela, in the International Court of Justice on Thursday.

item.title: After U.S.-Led Strikes in Yemen, How Wide Will the Middle East War Get?
item.description: With the U.S.-led attacks in Yemen, there is no longer a question of whether the Israel-Hamas war will escalate into a wider conflict. The question is whether it can be contained.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, David E. Sanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Osamah Yahya/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters during a parade in December in Amran Province, Yemen.

item.title: It’s a monster election year. Don’t let the horse race distract you.
item.description: Our institutions are in decline, and we need to pay attention.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Institutions, like the London Underground, exist so that complex processes can become automatic.

item.title: Pope Cites Bronchitis as He Skips Speaking to Audiences at the Vatican
item.description: Instead, the pontiff’s words were handed out in written form. He seemed to be in good spirits, though his health has become an increasing concern.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Andrew Medichini/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for his weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday.
